text: The major protein complexes of electron transport each have one or more redox centers containing either [4Fe-4S]—the metal atoms provide the site for a small by a transferred electron converts the iron to Fe2+.
Transition metals make useful electron carriers because their outer electron shell has several closely spaced energy levels, facilitating small energy transitions.

The heme plays a key role in acquiring and transferring electrons, such as Geobacter may make over a hundred different types of cytochromes in its envelope, where electrons accumulate until the bacterium finds an oxidant to accept them.
Its reddish color derives from the buried cofactor called heme, a ring of conjugated double bonds surrounding an iron ion (Fe2+ or Fe3+).

The branching of side chains on the ring varies among different Some electron carriers are small molecules that associate loosely with a protein complex and then come off to which can be reduced to quinols: Quinols carry electrons and protons laterally within the membrane between the proton-pumping protein complexes to the next protein complex, quinols revert to quinones, capable of accepting electrons again.
often coordinated by sulfur atoms of cysteine residues [2Fe-2S] and [4Fe-4S].
The protein, cytochrome c, transfers electrons for nitrate respiration.
